paragraphs.name: ec2d
paragraphs.text: The reality is that you might be better off doing less activity but doing “the right” activities really well. To do the right activities you need to start with a top down assessment with what you’re trying to achieve in your organization.
So my corollary has always been “doing the right things is more important than doing things right.” Sounds simple but in practice I promise you most organization fall into the latter trap.
paragraphs.name: 000a

paragraphs.text: The reality is that you might be better off doing less activity but doing “the right” activities really well. To do the right activities you need to start with a top down assessment with what you’re trying to achieve in your organization.
paragraphs.name: ec2d
1b30
paragraphs.text: It’s the parable of the tree-chopping team that is so focused on efficiency of how fast it can fell a tree that it doesn’t bother to make sure it is clearing the forest in the right direction when one person actually stops the constant cutting to climb a tree and make sure they’re cutting in the right direction. On the surface this person is losing efficiency but in the long-run the gains for direction setting are huge.

paragraphs.name: 86aa
paragraphs.text: You have a marketing department with three people. They’re tasked with doing … marketing. So they create a task list of all the marketing activities an organization can do: press releases, web site updates, customer case studies, blog posts, daily Tweets, Facebook fan page, attending conferences, etc. You get a lot of traffic — not always results. If you aren’t careful every PR team will measure inches over impact. Vanity metrics will make you feel good about site traffic of SEO over conversion rate or purchases of your product will get more attention than retention. Efficiency can be an addictive drug.

f3763a621e17.title: This is an awesome post Mark Suster and one that really hits home!

paragraphs.text: This is an awesome post Mark Suster and one that really hits home! As a CEO I find myself asking my team and my board if we’re doing the right thing whilst being absolutely convinced we are.
Every opportunity, every piece of PR, every speaking opporunity we ask ourselves — what is the end goal? What are we trying to achieve…

paragraphs.text: Good point. Plus, a lot of the things that matter can’t be quantified into a single measurement to begin with (which is why cost-cutting tends to dampen innovation).
paragraphs.name: 55a5

60899a2b996e.title: Hopefully somebody’s asking whether the forest should be cleared in the first place.

paragraphs.text: Hopefully somebody’s asking whether the forest should be cleared in the first place. Increasingly, not asking and answering questions at that level is what’s going to get us all into trouble. Whether it’s Zuckerberg failing to ask and adequately answer questions on news and democracy (yes, I read the manifesto) or the CEO of some defense-tech company…

304fb11ffd79.title: This is a simplified representation of Steven Covey’s rule, Begin with the End in Mind.

paragraphs.text: This is a simplified representation of Steven Covey’s rule, Begin with the End in Mind. Having the outcome determine action is so crucial to maximize your time and effort.
paragraphs.name: eb9d

paragraphs.text: Awesome post! I believe this is a direct parallel to smart ‘product strategy and thinking’ as well….simply releasing a lot of features and updates might be ‘efficient’ and feel like ‘movement’, but it’s also a vanity metric. Your post applies this logic to the entire company, which I completely agree with. ‘Your product isn’t the product, the company…

3b4e352e02da.title: The headline and the gist of this article reminded me of what one of the great sayings that the…

paragraphs.text: The headline and the gist of this article reminded me of what one of the great sayings that the late leadership expert Warren Bennis taught at USC Marshall Business School, “ Managers do things right but leaders do the right thing.
paragraphs.name: d2fa

paragraphs.text: So critical for small companies. Start with the result you wish to achieve and manage to it. Allows you to maintain focus and remove distractions.
paragraphs.name: b89b

917f1b4576e5.title: Agree. It is difficult because we startupper have always really few time, but we must reserve some…

paragraphs.text: Agree. It is difficult because we startupper have always really few time, but we must reserve some time each week to understand if we’re heading the right direction or we’re doing only useless actions. It’s hard and I admit that most of weeks I don’t do this… thanks for sharing this article
paragraphs.name: 9ec5

bd6e67e107c0.title: Effectiveness over efficiency is another way to put it.

paragraphs.text: Effectiveness over efficiency is another way to put it.
paragraphs.name: a94d

paragraphs.text: Great post. And I think it applies to VCs as well. As an investor one can go on running around “sourcing” deals, attending events, grabbing coffees, and even blogging, but in the end it might not translate well into actual results. Its always useful to use a top down approach and figure out your tactics from your strategy. Tactics without a coherent strategy almost always turn out to be useless.
paragraphs.name: d49c

582f4f6d3a74.title: I used this quote incessantly when building design-led engineering organizations.

paragraphs.text: I used this quote incessantly when building design-led engineering organizations. Engineering best-practices, and disciplines such as agile or software craftsmanship rightly obsess about “doing things right”.
But design-thinking; making sure you frame the problem through the lens of a user need and then designing a solution…
